Awesome Programmer RostakaGmfun's blog

XML file parsing in C++

13 Oct 2013

Introduction

XML files are widely used today so it is great to know how to parse them.

One good XML file parsing library is rapidxml. It is distributed as a collection of header files and can be downloaded from it’s official site.

Getting started

So, lets start. First, we’ll just read the contents of the simplest ever xml file:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<root>
    <node1>
        Contents of node 1
    </node1>
</root>

Open your favourite text editor or IDE and let’s do some coding:

 1 #include <iostream>
 2 
 3     #include "rapidxml/rapidxml.hpp"
 4     #include "rapidxml/rapidxml_utils.hpp"
 5 
 6     using namespace rapidxml;
 7     using namespace std;
 8 
 9     int main(void)
10     {
11         xml_document<> doc; //create xml_document object
12         file<> xmlFile("sample.xml"); //open file
13         doc.parse<0>(xmlFile.data()); //parse the contents of file
14         xml_node<>* root = doc.first_node("root");//find our root node
15         xml_node<>* node1 = root->first_node("node1"); //find our node1 node
16 
17         cout << node1->value() << "\n"; //print node1 value
18 
19         return 0;
20     }

Compiling

To compile your source under Debian or other Debian-like Linux distro first make sure g++ package is installed:

$sudo apt-get install g++

After that you can compile your source:

$g++ -o rapidxml_demo rapidxml_demo.cpp

To run the executable type:

$./rapidxml_demo

The output should be something like that:

Contents of node 1

Writing XML file

Except parsing rapidxml features writing in XML format. So, let’s look on another example:

 1 #include <string>
 2 #include <iostream>
 3 #include <fstream> //for file output
 4 #include <iterator>//for std::back_inserter
 5 
 6 #include "rapidxml/rapidxml.hpp"
 7 
 8 #include "rapidxml/rapidxml_print.hpp"
 9 
10 
11 using namespace std;
12 
13 
14 int main(void)
15 {
16  rapidxml::xml_document<> doc;
17  ofstream out("sample2.xml");
18 
19  // xml declaration node
20  rapidxml::xml_node<>* decl = doc.allocate_node(rapidxml::node_declaration); //allocate default xml declaration node
21  //apppend special attributes to it
22  decl->append_attribute(doc.allocate_attribute("version", "1.0"));
23  decl->append_attribute(doc.allocate_attribute("encoding", "utf-8"));
24  doc.append_node(decl); //finally, append node
25 
26  //allocate root node
27  rapidxml::xml_node<>* root = doc.allocate_node(rapidxml::node_element,"root"); //node element is the type of node
28  doc.append_node(root);
29 
30 
31  //node1
32  rapidxml::xml_node<>* node1 = doc.allocate_node(rapidxml::node_element,"node1");
33  node1->value("Contents of node1");
34  root->append_node(node1);
35 
36  //root2
37  rapidxml::xml_node<>* root2 = doc.allocate_node(rapidxml::node_element,"root2");
38  root2->value("Contetns of root2");
39  doc.append_node(root2);
40 
41 
42  string xml_as_string;
43  rapidxml::print(back_inserter(xml_as_string), doc);//print formatted XML to a string
44 
45  out<<xml_as_string;
46  out.close();
47 
48  return 0;
49 }

If you compile this you will have quite a lot compile errors. That is because of specific behavior of newer versions of g++. In order to fix the problem add the following code in the rapidxml_print.hpp file on line 31:

 1 template<class OutIt, class Ch>
 2  inline OutIt print(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> &amp;node, int flags = 0);
 3  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
 4  inline OutIt print_node(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);
 5  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
 6  inline OutIt print_children(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);
 7  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
 8  inline OutIt print_element_node(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);
 9  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
10  inline OutIt print_data_node(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);
11  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
12  inline OutIt print_cdata_node(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);
13  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
14  inline OutIt print_declaration_node(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);
15  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
16  inline OutIt print_comment_node(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);
17  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
18  inline OutIt print_doctype_node(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);
19  template<class OutIt, class Ch>
20  inline OutIt print_pi_node(OutIt out, const xml_node<Ch> *node, int flags, int indent);

This will make the internal rapidxml functions visible to g++. Now compile the code, run and look at the file generated. The contents of sample2.xml should be like this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<root>
<node1>Contents of node1</node1>
</root>
<root2>Contetns of root2</root2>

At this point you are able to write and read XML files. If you have any questions feel free to contact me.
